VARSITY SWIMMING TEAM
FALLS BEFORE UNIVERSITY OF PITTSBURG'S
STRONG TEAM

BALTIMORE, MD. FEBRUARY 8, 1921
OLYMPIC STARS TO VIE
WITH HOME TALENT AT
HOPKINS INDOOR MEET
Leading Colleges and Clubs Enter

Every Finish Close—Hall Lowers Back
Stroke Record by Four-Fifths
Second.

Saturday afternoon the University of Pittsburgh defeated Hopkins' swimming team in the Baltimore Athletic Club pool by the
score of 44 to 26. The Pittsburghers were represented by an exceptionally fast, strong team, and one
that will give much concern to all
its future opponents. Especially
were they strong in the dashes,
placing first in the 40, 100 and 220yard events.
Pitt won the first event—the
relay—in the fast time of 1 minute 24 seconds; the lead gained by
the first Pitt swimmers was too
great to be overcome, with the result that Rowland finished five
feet behind Corr.
In the fancy dive, Call was defeated by Kistler; both gave excellent exhibitions and were loudly
applauded.
Hall, swimming the 40-yard
breast stroke, • broke the record
made by Reins in the Swarthmore
meet several weeks ago, going the
5 .seconds, a new
distance in 261/
Hopkins record by 4
/
5 of a second.
Hambletdn, who holds the Hopkins record for the plunge, was defeated by Clark of Pitt, whose distance was 58 feet, 11/
2 feet less
than that plunged by Hambleton
in the Swarthmore meet.
The 220-yard dash was nip and
tuck throughout the greater part
of the distance, but Corr, who
proved to be Pitt's individual star,
gradually drew away from Coady
on the final lap, beating him out
by only a few inches..
Rowland swain a good race in
the 60-yard breast stroke event,
finishing well in front of Taylbr,
Pitt's entrant.

meet, in which Thoma of Pitt won,

American Legion Dance.

The American Legion has reluested the Military Office to an-N
hounce to the students of the
University that there will be an
American Legion dance at the
Fifth Regiment Armory Tuesday, February 8, from 9.30 P.
1r. to 1 A. M. Farson's oechesIra of 30 pieces will play.
Those who desire to attend
this dance may obtain tickets
from the Military Office. The
proceeds of this dance will be
for the benefit of the American
Legion.

Best Men for Annual Black and
Blue Classic.

Entries already received for the
Hopkins-Fifth Regiment Indoor
Track Meet assure its being one of
the most important meets held this
winter. The high-class competition, the big-league management,'
the tempting prizes and undoubted
prestige of the meet have attracted the best track and field
men from 30 of the leading Eastern colleges. Not only are these
men college, stars of the first water, but several have international
reputations through their work in
the last Olympic games.
Colleges and clubs from all over
the East have been keeping
"Teddy" Kistler, secretary of the
games committee, on the jump answering requests for information,
arranging special competitions
and filing away entrance blanks.
Princeton, Penn Penn State, Syra
Tech, Pittsburgh,
cuse, Georgia '
Virginia, Georgetown and Washington and Lee are sending their
best men in an effort to take home
the lion's share of the prizes. The
leading clubs will also be represented by unusually strcong teams,
and the high schools of three
States and Canada are looking
upon the meet as the crowning
event of the season.
Many of the most famous middle-distance men of the country
will be on hand when the starter's
gun sends away specially nominated men from 30 or more picked
colleges in their quest for the
laurels and the cup that goes annually to the winner of the 1000yard Varsity Special Race. Schoolboys picked from the best Canadian scholastic distance runners
will race City College's bang-up
team in the interesting International Schoolboy Four-mile Relay. The Maryland Interscholastic
Athletic Association, the South
Atlantic Intercollegiate Athletic
Association, the Middle States
Conference will stage some or all
of their championship indoor
events before the eyes of thousands of Baltimoreans gathered to
see the greatest indoor athletic
meet ever put on in Baltimore.
Some of the more famous college athletes who have already signified their intention of competing
are Romig of Penn State; Watson
and Woodring, the Olympic sensation, of Syracuse; Crawford and
Lecony of Lafayette; Bawden -of
Mass. Tech.; Landin, Yale's highjump star; Penfield and McCullough of Princeton; Higgins, Co(Continued on page 8, col. 2)

HAVERFORD AND TOME FALL
BEFORE HOPKINS COURTMEN
Varsity Takes Game from Quakers by One Point—Contest Hotly
Fonght—Bill Wood in Spotlight—Freshmen
Oulclass Port Deposit Lads
The Fifth Regiment Armory was last Friday night the scene of a
double victory for the Black and Blue basket-ball squads when the
Varsity won a thrilling one-point victory, 20 to 19, from Haverford
College, while the Freshman quint preceded them by downing Tome
School by the comfortable score of 31 to 18. Both contests were hotly
fought from beginning to end, and were, as a whole, well played.
The Varsity contest was a neck-and-neck affair, with neither side
able to draw away from its hard-playing opponent. Bobby Owings
opened up with a field goal, but Haverford came back with a pair of
foul shots; from then to the end of the first period the lead was changed
back and forth. Hopkins managed to end the half with the count 15 to
10 in its favor.
The Quakers soon tied the score, and then went into the lead; Hopkins scored a field goal and a foul, and Matzke made it 18 all with a
pretty shot from the floor. Finally the Pennsylvanians again went
ahead when Owings missed on Hopkins' end of a double foul.

In oue of the fastest games ever
played on the Coliseum floor in
Washington the Johns Hopkins
five defeated George Washington
University by the score of 32 to
29.
The Black and Blue team put
up an exhibition of teamwork that
far surpassed that shown in any
of the previous games this season.
Not only teamwork but sheer fighting and gameness also helped to
put the game on ice in the second
half. At the end of the first period
the score stood 19 to 11 in favor
of the Hatchetites.
Long and difficult shots by both
Owings and Barrett in the second
half put Hopkins in the lead and
they were never passed after they
had registered 25 points.
Martin, a freshman, got into the
game for a short time and showed
to good advantage.

ORATORICAL CLUB ARRANGES DEBATE WITH
LOYOLA COLLEGE
Tryouts On Wednesday—All Students
Eligible—Restriction of Immigration the Subject—Varsity
Has Affirmative.

The Oratorical Club has finally
concluded the arrangements with
Loyola College for the debate
which has been pending for several weeks. Although the debate
is under the auspices of the Oratorical Club the tryouts will be
open to all undergraduates. The
debate will be held Wednesday,
March 9, in the Loyola College
Hall.
The subject is "Resolved, That
immigration into the United
States, with the exception of the
immediate family of the present
citizens, be prohibited for a period
of three years." The Oratorical
Club will uphold the affirmative.
Tryouts will be held Wednesday,
February 9, at 12.20 o'clock, in
Room 112, Gilman Hall.

FRESHMAN FIVE A VICTOR
AT IRVINGTON LAST
WEEK
Defeats Fast Mt. St Joseph's Squad, 23
to 19—Ashton and Hutzler
Show Fine Form.

Johns Hopkins Freshies defeated Mount St. Joseph's on
Mount St. Joseph's floor by the
score 23 to 19 in a thrilling game
January 28.
At the end of the first half the
score was 17 to 17. Mount St.
Joseph's was able to score only
two points in the second half,
while Hopkins registered six, due
to the brilliant work of Ashton at
forward. Hutzler played a good
game at center, scoring 8 of the
23 points made by his team. The
game was fast at every stage and
was marked by hard play on the
part of both teams.

SCIENTIFIC CLUB WILL HEAR
LECTURE ON MARS
'Frederick Brackett To Present Latest
Views On Subject—Has Worked
At Mt. Wilson Observatory.
Interest of Subject Promises Large Attendance.

What do you know about Mars?
Is it inhabited? What light does
modern astronomy cast on this
subject? What is its population?
Has it any canals?
Mr. Frederick Brackett of the
physics department will bring the
latest views on this subject before
the Scientific Club on Thursday at
12.30 P. M. in Room 2, Gilman
Hall.
Mr. Brackett has been solar observer at Mt. Wilson Observatory,
where he was intimately associated
with Dr. Hale. He is at present
associated with Dr. Pfund in spectroscopic research. During the
war Mr. Brackett was called to
Washington, where he was connected with the Bureau of Weights
and Standards. His work there
was a great success. His specialty
is in optics, in which line his colleagues acknowledge that he will
be an important factor in the
future. He will present to the
club the latest astronomical views
and scientific theories on the subject of the day. This lecture will
probably be the most interesting
of any that the club has had so
far,, because of the competence of
the' lecturer and of his ability to
present difficult subjects in a popular form. Because of the interest
that this subject arouses the club
expects a large attendance.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEB. 8, 1921
Knocking the Knockers.

Those undergraduates who spend
the greater part of their spare time
criticising the way things are going at Hopkins should pause and
consider what effort they themselves are making to remedy the
existing state of affairs. Instead
of criticising destructively, they
should criticise constructively. Instead of standing on the concrete
roadbed watching and telling the
"other fellow" how to get the wagon out of the ditch, they should
take off their coats and put their
own shoulders to the whee I.
Knocking by itself never accomplishes anything and knockers seldom get anywhere.

The College as a Liberal Influence.

The advantages, other than material, of a college education have
'been excellently enumerated by
former President Hyde of Bowdoin College, who said:
"To be at home in all lands.and
all ages; to count nature a fain-

iliar acquaintance and art an intimate friend;.to gain a standard
for the appreciation of other men's
work and the criticism of one's
own; to carry the keys of the
world's library in one's pocket,
and feel its resources behind one
in whatever task he undertakes;
to make hosts of friends among
the men of one's own age who are
to be leaders in all walks of life;
to lose oneself in generous enthusiasm and co-operate with others for common ends; to learn
manners from students who are
gentlemen, and to form character
under professors who are Chris• tian§, these are the returns of a
college for the best four years of
ones life."
The purpose of an undergraduate course is not the development
of scholastic peaks; it is the broad• ening of the individual and in preparing and equipping him to meet
the many problems which he will
have to face in the business world
that the college is chiefly interested.
The man who is at home only in
the classroom, who is capable of
thinking only in the light of the
knowledge which he has absorbed
• through the courses he has covered, is no more a true representative or product of a college education than is the solid-ivory athlete,
whose only place is on the athletic
field. It is the all-round man, the
man who is prepared to think and
think accurately, who are "versatile, alert, with some knowledge of
economics, history and social science, with evidence of capacity for
executive work," who best typifles
the advantages of the college environment.
What Hopkins needs is not a
higher scholastic standard; that
which we have places us in the
ranks of the foremost colleges in
the country; we need a greater
percentage of participants in college activities, a greater amount
of college life and college spirit,
and more interchange of ideas
among the undergraduates themselves.
The mid-year examinations are
now a bugbear of the past, and
the time has come for every student at the university, and especially those of the entering class,
to identify themselves with some
college activity, and, by working
on it, not only help advance the
university, but broaden his own
experience, develop his executive
ability and prepare himself to
meet the problems he must face on
leaving college.

some Hopkins men. Other similar
opportunities are likely to be offered in the course of the spring
months.

in the following inquiries from

in physics and mathematics.

Spanish, possibly also German).

The Social Science Club was addressed by Dr. Harry W. Laidler
on the Monday before examinations on "Guild Socialism." Dr.
Laidler gave a very interesting
synopsis of the development of
Socialism from its earliest days up
to the present time. The first
school of Socialism was the Utopian, then came the Marxian school
with its communist manifesto, followed by the German revisionists
and the syndicalists, who believed
in the abolition of the political
state and a new society to be
formed by direct action of the
workers. The fifth great school is
that of Guild Socialism.
The followers of this branch of
Socialism believe in the ownership'
of industry by the State with management in the hands of the intellectual and manual workers who
are to be formed in local, sectional
and national guilds. This, according to Dr. Laidler, is "a reaction
against State Socialism and to
some extent against syndicalism."
Guild Socialists believe in preserving the political state while according the workers complete management of all industry. This,
they declare, necessary to give
labor a respectability and responsibility which the present system
of wages, by making manual
workers a commodity, can never
give. The people as consumers
would have a voice concerning
products and prices to prevent
their exploitation by the guilds.
The officers in industry, such as
foremen, are to be elected directly
by the workers, which plan is expected to give more efficiency than
our own, since no one will be eligible for election who has not passed
an examination set by some outside agency. One great danger,
Dr. Laidler said, is that society
will come to regard production
and not consumption as the great
human ultimate.
The lecture was well attended
and the subject was clearly and
lucidly set forth by the speaker.
After his talk Dr, Laidler answered a number of questions on
a great many aspects of the subject.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 8, 1921
CAST FOR DRAMATIC CLUB
PRODUCTION CHOSEN
Moran and Trew To Have Star Parts.
Work Resumed On Rehearsals.
Ticket Sale Starts
February 15.

Tickets for the performance will
be issued on February 15 and will
be sold at the Studio in the "Barn"
and by every member of the cast.

After a change of labors for examination week the Dramatic Club
has started again on its rehearsals
for "Arms and the Man," the play
by George Bernard Shaw, which
will be put on in the Lyric March
11. Concentrated effort is being
exerted in order to have all of the
cast developed into finished actors
in the short month which is left
before that date. It will mean
much work for the eight men in
the cast and the assistants who
are preparing the costumes and
the scenery. Miss Walter will be
on hand at each of the five rehearsals held each week to do the directing, besides giving each man
private coaching in her studio.
The cast as selected will be:
Catherine, E. M. Basford, '21;
Raina, J. A. Moran,'23; Louka, H.
D. West,'23; Petkoff, H.P. Brawner, '23; Sergius, Gilson Engel,
'21; Bulunsheldi, Bartus Trew,
'21; Nicola, D. S. Mossom,'21, and
Captain of Guards, E. H. Cashell,
'22. Soldiers and attendants not
Chosen.
Bartus Trew, as the .hero, and
Joseph Moran, as the heorine, are
among the best actors that the
club has ever produced and in
"Arms and the Man" will have
ample opportunity to display their
talents in parts that require emotional as well as serious interludes. Engel and Brawner both
have roles which require most
rigid attention to detail.

Saturday afternoon the University of Pittsburgh defeated Hopkins' swimming team in the Baltimore Athletic Club pool by the

its future opponents. Especially
were they strong in the dashes,
placing first in the 40, 100 and 220yard events.

relay—in the fast time of 1 minute 24 seconds; the lead gained by

feet behind Corr.

applauded.

Entries already received for the
Hopkins-Fifth Regiment Indoor
Track Meet assure its being one of
the most important meets held this
winter. The high-class competition, the big-league management,'
the tempting prizes and undoubted
prestige of the meet have attracted the best track and field
men from 30 of the leading Eastern colleges. Not only are these
men college, stars of the first water, but several have international
reputations through their work in
the last Olympic games.
Colleges and clubs from all over
the East have been keeping
"Teddy" Kistler, secretary of the
games committee, on the jump answering requests for information,
arranging special competitions
and filing away entrance blanks.
Princeton, Penn Penn State, Syra
Tech, Pittsburgh,
cuse, Georgia '

best men in an effort to take home

The Fifth Regiment Armory was last Friday night the scene of a
double victory for the Black and Blue basket-ball squads when the
Varsity won a thrilling one-point victory, 20 to 19, from Haverford
College, while the Freshman quint preceded them by downing Tome
School by the comfortable score of 31 to 18. Both contests were hotly
fought from beginning to end, and were, as a whole, well played.
The Varsity contest was a neck-and-neck affair, with neither side
able to draw away from its hard-playing opponent. Bobby Owings
opened up with a field goal, but Haverford came back with a pair of
foul shots; from then to the end of the first period the lead was changed
back and forth. Hopkins managed to end the half with the count 15 to
10 in its favor.
The Quakers soon tied the score, and then went into the lead; Hopkins scored a field goal and a foul, and Matzke made it 18 all with a
pretty shot from the floor. Finally the Pennsylvanians again went
ahead when Owings missed on Hopkins' end of a double foul.

ORATORICAL CLUB ARRANGES DEBATE WITH
LOYOLA COLLEGE
Tryouts On Wednesday—All Students
Eligible—Restriction of Immigration the Subject—Varsity
Has Affirmative.

The Oratorical Club has finally
concluded the arrangements with
Loyola College for the debate
which has been pending for several weeks. Although the debate
is under the auspices of the Oratorical Club the tryouts will be
open to all undergraduates. The
debate will be held Wednesday,
March 9, in the Loyola College
Hall.
The subject is "Resolved, That
immigration into the United
States, with the exception of the
immediate family of the present
citizens, be prohibited for a period
of three years." The Oratorical
Club will uphold the affirmative.
Tryouts will be held Wednesday,
February 9, at 12.20 o'clock, in
Room 112, Gilman Hall.

SCIENTIFIC CLUB WILL HEAR
LECTURE ON MARS
'Frederick Brackett To Present Latest
Views On Subject—Has Worked
At Mt. Wilson Observatory.
Interest of Subject Promises Large Attendance.

What do you know about Mars?
Is it inhabited? What light does
modern astronomy cast on this
subject? What is its population?
Has it any canals?
Mr. Frederick Brackett of the
physics department will bring the
latest views on this subject before
the Scientific Club on Thursday at
12.30 P. M. in Room 2, Gilman
Hall.
Mr. Brackett has been solar observer at Mt. Wilson Observatory,
where he was intimately associated
with Dr. Hale. He is at present
associated with Dr. Pfund in spectroscopic research. During the
war Mr. Brackett was called to
Washington, where he was connected with the Bureau of Weights
and Standards. His work there
was a great success. His specialty
is in optics, in which line his colleagues acknowledge that he will
be an important factor in the
future. He will present to the
club the latest astronomical views
and scientific theories on the subject of the day. This lecture will
probably be the most interesting
of any that the club has had so
far,, because of the competence of
the' lecturer and of his ability to
present difficult subjects in a popular form. Because of the interest
that this subject arouses the club
expects a large attendance.

BALTIMORE, MD., FEB. 8, 1921
Knocking the Knockers.

Those undergraduates who spend
the greater part of their spare time
criticising the way things are going at Hopkins should pause and
consider what effort they themselves are making to remedy the
existing state of affairs. Instead
of criticising destructively, they
should criticise constructively. Instead of standing on the concrete
roadbed watching and telling the
"other fellow" how to get the wagon out of the ditch, they should
take off their coats and put their
own shoulders to the whee I.
Knocking by itself never accomplishes anything and knockers seldom get anywhere.

The College as a Liberal Influence.

The advantages, other than material, of a college education have
'been excellently enumerated by
former President Hyde of Bowdoin College, who said:
"To be at home in all lands.and
all ages; to count nature a fain-

iliar acquaintance and art an intimate friend;.to gain a standard
for the appreciation of other men's
work and the criticism of one's
own; to carry the keys of the
world's library in one's pocket,
and feel its resources behind one
in whatever task he undertakes;
to make hosts of friends among
the men of one's own age who are
to be leaders in all walks of life;
to lose oneself in generous enthusiasm and co-operate with others for common ends; to learn
manners from students who are
gentlemen, and to form character
under professors who are Chris• tian§, these are the returns of a
college for the best four years of
ones life."
The purpose of an undergraduate course is not the development
of scholastic peaks; it is the broad• ening of the individual and in preparing and equipping him to meet
the many problems which he will
have to face in the business world
that the college is chiefly interested.
The man who is at home only in
the classroom, who is capable of
thinking only in the light of the
knowledge which he has absorbed
• through the courses he has covered, is no more a true representative or product of a college education than is the solid-ivory athlete,
whose only place is on the athletic
field. It is the all-round man, the
man who is prepared to think and
think accurately, who are "versatile, alert, with some knowledge of
economics, history and social science, with evidence of capacity for
executive work," who best typifles
the advantages of the college environment.
What Hopkins needs is not a
higher scholastic standard; that
which we have places us in the
ranks of the foremost colleges in
the country; we need a greater
percentage of participants in college activities, a greater amount
of college life and college spirit,
and more interchange of ideas
among the undergraduates themselves.
The mid-year examinations are
now a bugbear of the past, and
the time has come for every student at the university, and especially those of the entering class,
to identify themselves with some
college activity, and, by working
on it, not only help advance the
university, but broaden his own
experience, develop his executive
ability and prepare himself to
meet the problems he must face on
leaving college.

Inquiries that are coming in
daily to the Bureau of Appointments.indicate that the shortage
of teachers still exists and that
the present depression in business
has not caused employment managers to lose interest in college
men. All Seniors who have not
made their plans for next year
would be wise to register at once
with the bureau and to examine
its files from time to time. A large
department store in New York
City which maintains a sort of
school for college men and pays
them $25 a week while their fitness for a place in the organization is being determined asks for
some Hopkins men. Other similar
opportunities are likely to be offered in the course of the spring
months.
Graduate students who wish to
teach next year may be in tere-led
in the following inquiries from
schools and colleges for teachers
for 1921-1922:
1. In a Southern college: A professor of biology, a professor of
Spanish, an associate professor of
German and French, an adjunct
professor of English, an instructor
in physics and mathematics.
2. A college for women in New
York State: A woman (with Ph.
D.) to head the English department, a head of the modern lan•
guage department (French and
Spanish, possibly also German).
3. A large university in Ohio:
Three or four instructors in
French and Spanish.
4. A college for women in New
York State: An instructor in English.
5. A college in Western Pennsylvania: Assistant professors in
biology, in chemistry, in modern
languages, an instructor in English.

The Rifle Club started its first
match of the intercollegiates during the latter part of last week.
In these contests 10 men take part
and the highest five scores represent the university. At the time
this issue goes to press seven men
have shot, the five highest b3itig
Ross, 80 out of a possible 100; C.
R. Stouck, 71 Rothholz, 62 Chisholm, 70, and E. H. Salter, 70. Of
course, if the three men yet to
shoot make higher scores the aforenamed will be displaced.
There are over a hundred colleges taking part in the competition and all the scores will be in
and results announced by the end
of the week. There will be a match
held every week in the future.
Captain McMurray said the scores
are extremely good in consideration of the fact that it is the first
time that the club has engaged in
an intercollegiate match.

The Social Science Club was addressed by Dr. Harry W. Laidler
on the Monday before examinations on "Guild Socialism." Dr.
Laidler gave a very interesting
synopsis of the development of
Socialism from its earliest days up
to the present time. The first
school of Socialism was the Utopian, then came the Marxian school
with its communist manifesto, followed by the German revisionists
and the syndicalists, who believed
in the abolition of the political
state and a new society to be
formed by direct action of the
workers. The fifth great school is
that of Guild Socialism.
The followers of this branch of
Socialism believe in the ownership'
of industry by the State with management in the hands of the intellectual and manual workers who
are to be formed in local, sectional
and national guilds. This, according to Dr. Laidler, is "a reaction
against State Socialism and to
some extent against syndicalism."
Guild Socialists believe in preserving the political state while according the workers complete management of all industry. This,
they declare, necessary to give
labor a respectability and responsibility which the present system
of wages, by making manual
workers a commodity, can never
give. The people as consumers
would have a voice concerning
products and prices to prevent
their exploitation by the guilds.
The officers in industry, such as
foremen, are to be elected directly
by the workers, which plan is expected to give more efficiency than
our own, since no one will be eligible for election who has not passed
an examination set by some outside agency. One great danger,
Dr. Laidler said, is that society
will come to regard production
and not consumption as the great
human ultimate.
The lecture was well attended
and the subject was clearly and
lucidly set forth by the speaker.
After his talk Dr, Laidler answered a number of questions on
a great many aspects of the subject.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 8, 1921
CAST FOR DRAMATIC CLUB
PRODUCTION CHOSEN
Moran and Trew To Have Star Parts.
Work Resumed On Rehearsals.
Ticket Sale Starts
February 15.

Tickets for the performance will
be issued on February 15 and will
be sold at the Studio in the "Barn"
and by every member of the cast.

After a change of labors for examination week the Dramatic Club
has started again on its rehearsals
for "Arms and the Man," the play
by George Bernard Shaw, which
will be put on in the Lyric March
11. Concentrated effort is being
exerted in order to have all of the
cast developed into finished actors
in the short month which is left
before that date. It will mean
much work for the eight men in
the cast and the assistants who
are preparing the costumes and
the scenery. Miss Walter will be
on hand at each of the five rehearsals held each week to do the directing, besides giving each man
private coaching in her studio.
The cast as selected will be:
Catherine, E. M. Basford, '21;
Raina, J. A. Moran,'23; Louka, H.
D. West,'23; Petkoff, H.P. Brawner, '23; Sergius, Gilson Engel,
'21; Bulunsheldi, Bartus Trew,
'21; Nicola, D. S. Mossom,'21, and
Captain of Guards, E. H. Cashell,
'22. Soldiers and attendants not
Chosen.
Bartus Trew, as the .hero, and
Joseph Moran, as the heorine, are
among the best actors that the
club has ever produced and in
"Arms and the Man" will have
ample opportunity to display their
talents in parts that require emotional as well as serious interludes. Engel and Brawner both
have roles which require most
rigid attention to detail.
